page.line: After I had been in
this army about a month
it first occurred to me
that a diary from my first
day should have been kept
but since it hadn't[,] I let it
go[,] assuming that the first
month was likely the most
interesting anyway. Six months
later I could see that lots of
interest had happened and that
I should have started even
a month late, but as before,
I figured the first few
months were doubtless
the most eventful and that
a diary of such a late start
would be dull. When
at Camp Kilmer, New Jersey I
once again considered the
matter + resolved to start
a diary from the day we
embarked but could not
find suitable notebook
at the P.X.1 and we were
confined to the post. Soon
afterwards I was told that
diarys [sic] overseas were not
permitted so I dismissed
the idea when in Camp
Anza2, California. Now at
the camp located around
Ledo in the province of
Assam in India the
story starts with a
summary of the first 20
months followed up as
a diary. R.P.P.

footnotes.note: 1. P.X.: "Post Exchange". A commissary on a US Army Post.

2. Located at what is now Riverside, CA. According to Wikipedia, "The post was activated on December 2, 1942, initially designated as Arlington Staging Area, and renamed Camp Anza on December 12, 1942. Camp Anza was deactivated on March 31, 1946." (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camp_Anza; See also http://www.militarymuseum.org/CpAnza.html)

page.line: In January 1942, I hitch[-]hiked
to Fayetteville[[, Arkansas]] to the recruiting
office and took my physical.
I was slightly afraid I'd flunk
it due to sub-par eyesight.
Little did I realize that seeing
the wall on which the chart
hung would have been
good enough. After the exam
I returned home for two
weeks thinking Frank1 would
be home on furlough. There
again one could see my innocence
so far as the army goes. I actually
believed he would get a furlough
because one of his officers had
promised it him. Feb. 5th I left
Harrison[[, Arkansas]], again hitch hiking, and
went to the office in Fayetteville

footnotes.note: 1. Frank A. Phillips 1917-2012, the author's elder brother

page.line: + from there I was given a bus
ticket to Little Rock. The
trip took me through Ft. Smith
where I saw a large number
of busses tagged "Camp
Chaffee". I thought how
disgusting it would be to
be sent that close to home1
after joining this army in
hopes of a little travel
Arrived in L.R. [[Little Rock]] at 8 P.M. and
from Naval Recruiting office got
a ticket to Camp Robinson.
In the camp bus I received
a bit of good natured kidding
and comforting promises (edged
with sarcasm) pertaining to
my happy future. The driver
told me when we got to

footnotes.note: 1. Camp Chaffee, Arkansas is approximately 90 miles southwest of the author's home in Harrison, Arkansas

page.line: the reception center[,] and I hopped
out with all my worldly possessions
in my pockets and a big question
mark over my head. I stalked
thru the door marked "selecters{?}
report here" and did report in an
un-military manner. I was
taken to the mess hall and
received my first G. I. chow,
sauerkraut + weiners. I looked
at the ungodly amount and
wondered if the average soldier ate
such a bait regularly. I
was shown to a tent with five
other soldiers + slept on my
first G. I. bunk. Not being
able to curl up was indeed
a hardship. When the bugler
sounded [T]aps I bounded out
thinking it to be [R]eveille1. I
soon saw my mistake + went
back to bed. It rained and
the tent leaked[,] naturally.
After number 6 move[,] I saw
the futility + picked out the
smallest unoccupied drip
+ slept under it. The guard
awakened us for chow in
the typical army manner,
beating on the wall with
his club or the but[t] of
his unloaded rifle. Later
in the morning I was told to
fall out with the men in
civvies2 + still later got my
first rimming [reaming] for not being
back at the receiving office
at 8 A.M. as directed. I still

footnotes.note: 1. Army bugle calls: taps "[s]ignals that unauthorized lights are to be extinguished. This is the last call of the day. The call is also sounded at the completion of a military funeral ceremony." Reveille "[s]ignals the troops to awaken for morning roll call. Used to accompany the raising of the National Colors." (https://www.bands.army.mil/music/buglecalls/default.asp)
2. Civilian clothes

page.line: haven't figured out how to be 2
places at once[,] but the officers
still expect it + I'm studying on it.
That morning I raised my right
hand + took the oath. Feb 6-42.
The entire 10 days at the reception
center was spent in confusion.
Go here + get stuck. Go there +
take a test. Go to mess hall +
pull K. P.1 Go yonder + roll up
the tent flaps. Go back + fall
out on the double. The first
C. O. D.[? Carrier Onboard Delivery? Call of Duty? Chewing out d...?] I had to be the one
man out of 100 who was pivot{?}
man + such pivots{?}. After
rimming [reaming] number 2, I went to
the rear to be replaced by
a man of average intelligence.
Rimming [Reaming] number 3 came for

footnotes.note: 1. K. P. "kitchen patrol", military slang for mess-hall duties.

page.line: not halting in mid air on
the command "halt" as I
did my first side straddle
hop. I still can't halt in
mid air[,] but I've seen it
done. Feb 16 I was called
out with 35 others to go to
Camp Lee1, Virginia for basic
training in the Q. M. R. T. C.2
Arrived Feb 18 and was
assigned to Barracks T-438
Co. "B" 7th Q. M. Tng. Regt.
Third Platoon. Rifle no.
1101282. Had already received
ASN 12052321. When our
platoon Sgt., Sgt. Ward gave
us our first command[,] I knew
our troubles had started.
He was a Virginian + such

footnotes.note: 1. Camp Lee, now Fort Lee
2. Q. M. R. T. C. Quartermaster Replacement Training Center.

page.line: an accent! The basic as a
whole I enjoyed. A pleasant change
from working nights + I was
still bubbling over with enthus-
iasm + patriotism. The latter
I still possess[,] but the former
has petered out. I ate up the
C. O. D. + the hikes despite the
blisters. Scored 154 on the range
+ was ecstatic. Listened intently
to the classes + was an all
[a]round model soldier till lights
out + then I became talkative.
There was bitching from the
buddies{?} + rimming [reaming] from the
Sgt. but the talk continued
to a late hour nightly. The
search for VICKS invariably
followed the final warning
from the Sgt. or acting Cpl.
Underwood. Outstanding
names among the 35 Arkies
are Krieg{?}, Ritter, Whitten,
Hogan, Jesman{?}, Rosenthal,
Sheets, Murphy, Causy{?},
Chadwick, Bramlett, "Slim",
Sandler [Sandlin?], Brown, Thacker,
Roy, Spradlin, Delbert, Powell.
The awkward squad was
Davis and Henry. For a time
I feared I'd be a mechanic
but I was assigned to the
bakery school after the basic
military. The first field
bakery struck me as a sad
sack. I later realized the
truth of that first impression[,]
which subsided for a time.
By answering the right question
when Capt. McKuckin{?} was
listening I got my name on the
A. I. B.1 list. Also by
volunteering for a grass
detail I got around a rimming [reaming]
the day I should have been
fireman[,] and also got a better
stand in with the Capt. and
that resulted in my being
treated civil by Cpt. Clemish{?}.
Most unusual. By telling them
I'd planted lots of grass[,] I got
in charge of the detail +
instructed visiting non-coms
on grass sowing. Luckily I
got away in time to avoid
the rimming [reaming] of all time

footnotes.note: A. I. B. [? Armored Infantry Battalion? Army in Being?]

page.line: when the grass sprouted
not. At reveille April 9[,]
1st Sgt. Malloy (Tuffy{?}) called
me out to turn in my stuff.
I was leaving. After shaking
hands with the boys 4
different times[,] I left for
Chicago, Ill. on April 10-42
to attend the American
Institute of Baking for 5 wks.
We slept in the shed + worked
days a week + mornings a week [[sic]].
Joint classes with officers.
The 5 weeks was neither
pleasant nor unpleasant. Just
studying, working, and waiting
for the end of the 5 weeks
to see where next. The
meeting with Walter Hogan
and the Nagorsen{?} sisters killed
some of my time as did several
sight[-]seeing trips among which
was the one to Central Waxed
Paper Co. inspired by fond
memories. The baking class
was graduated + Lt. McKormick
gave each of us an insincere
hand clasp + each of us[,] in
turn[,] looked at his neck and
wondered how it would feel
the [[to]] throttle him. He's now
commanding a nigger baking
co. + I sincerely hope he's
in India. A horrid place.
He'd fit here. Prof. Walrusly{?}
we'll never forget. The same
for Eddie Killen. Erinson{?}
thought he'd made [[make?]] 1st Sgt. in
three months. Upon being
told groups were going to NC,
La., Mo., + Ark.[,] I immediately
resigned myself to going to
NC as that was farthest
from Ark. By then I'd gladly
have gone to Camp Chaffee
I did. Imagine that. We
left Chicago May 20 + got to
Camp Chaffee the 21st.
With me were Masck [Masik?], Brewer,
Schramm, Lokietz [Lakietz?], Muller
McCarthy, Havoner, + Hearn.
At present Masck{?} is a Lt. in another
Bkg. Co., Brewer is expected to
die in a nearby hospital
Sch[[r]]amm is a buck Sgt.1 with
me, Lokietz made limited service
+ signal corps in Crowder2.

footnotes.note: 1. "Sergeant is the enlisted rank in the U.S. Army above specialist and corporal and below staff sergeant, and is the second-lowest grade of non-commissioned officer. The rank was often nicknamed 'buck sergeant' to distinguish it from other senior grades of sergeants." (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergeant)

2. Camp Crowder, Missouri (A.K.A. Fort Crowder). "The United States Army Signal Corps (USASC) is a division of the Department of the Army that creates and manages communications and information systems for the command and control of combined arms forces." (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_Corps_(United_States_Army)

page.line: Muller is S/Sgt1 + Gestapo here,
Havoner was awkward long enough
to transfer + Hearn made C. C. S.2
After being built up at A. I. B.[,]
we were let down to sod
hauling + general landscaping +
manual labor. Co. C. 96QM
Bkng. Co. was activated April 20th[,]
1942. Cadre{?} came from B. 97
at Barkly [[Barclay?]], Texas. C. O.3 was
Zaller. David R. Newsom[,]
commonly known as Bo Bo
A. Scattergood{?} + now our
C. O. was also there. Sgts. were
Cavanaugh, House, Johnston,
Blew{?}, De Fontes, Bortz, + Walfe.
Cpl.4 Laurie + Pfc.5 Heft.
After a lot of sweating[,] we all
made Cpl. on June 10-42. I got

footnotes.note: 1. Staff Sergeant
2. C. C. S.: Combined Chiefs of Staff, the supreme military staff for the U. S. and Great Britain during WWII. [? or possibly Close Combat Systems]
3. C. O.: commanding officer
4. Cpl. Corporal
5. Pfc. (PFC): Private First Class

page.line: my first pass to go home on
June 13. First stripes sewed on
at home + they meant more than
any since. After 4 months at
$21[,] I made Cpl. the month I'd
been looking forward to $30
+ be darned if the pay raise
didn't go thru + the buck
privates made $50. Pulled
guard three times a week
all thru June + July + of
caught in on the 4th [[of July]].
Chow was with D-23[r]d +
about as good as the cats
eat at home. Not quite.
Finally[,] in July we opened our
mess + have eaten
well when our own cooks
were on the job ever since.
Some time in July Lt. Norris made
C. O. + captain. He was a
man + when we lost him
in January it made such a
difference in the discipline
+ ambition that the co.1 still
feels it, shows it, + with
the exception of the officers[,]
admits it. The officers who
came + went were Grey,
Zoller{?}, Scarborough, Earnest,
Rosen, Vial. There were few
men till July + before their
arrival we lived like a family
rather than soldiers. Aug 1[,]
due to a new J. O.[,]2 we
made Sgt. Muller, Havoner,
+ McCarthy were busted
for going to Dallas on a

footnotes.note: 1. co. (company): "a military unit, typically consisting of 80â€“150 soldiers and usually commanded by a major or a captain. Most companies are formed of three to six platoons, although the exact number may vary by country, unit type, and structure." (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Company_(military_unit)

2. J. O.: Junior officer "refers to the lowest operational commissioned officer category of ranks in a military or paramilitary organization, ranking above non-commissioned officers and below senior officers." (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Junior_officer)

page.line: Hot Springs pass. They were
busted because of the
inefficiency of Havoner + Mc
but the pass incident was
the excuse. After pulling
a string or three[,] I went on
maneuvers with the 1st Ptn. +
S/Sgt Blew{?}. Bo Bo was the
Lt. We left Aug 8-42.
We were attached to A-96th
for rations[,] which were
fish, sheep, + goat
A lot of fun, a lot of
work, + a lot of Bo Bo's
half[-]wit ideas such as
exercise platforms, drill field
C. O. D. + a public notice of
the best tent each day. There
was one trip to Chattanooga[,]
Ft. Oglethorp, + Lookout Mtn. We
went by truck + came back late.
Yambrick{?} was sick + drunk.
Phelps the victim of our
mischevious [mischievous] natures. I almost
went to O. C. S.1 from there ([Camp] Forrest)[,] but
at the last minute decided I'd
be better satisfied as an E. M.2
where I can do anything I can
get away with + be on or off
the ball depending on the mood.
I still think so. Oct. 22 we
went back to Chaffee + found
3 platoons of rookies + Brewer
pulling for S/Sgt. Said maneuvers
were 2nd army in Tennessee.
We were at Camp Forrest3 where
I had my first case of
the G. I.'s.4 Hospital 7 days.

footnotes.note: 1. O. C. S.: Officer Candidate School
2. E. M.: Enlisted Military, Enlisted Member

3. "Camp Forrest, located in Tullahoma, Tennessee, was one of the U.S. Army's largest training bases during World War II. It was an active army post between 1941 and 1946." (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camp_Forrest)

"a case of the GIs, an ailment usually associated with food from soapy pots and pans." (Hiley, Master Sgt. Julian. 1951. "The Army Needs Names" United States Army Combat Forces Journal; Vol. 2, No. 3, Oct; (pg RA3-PA18))

page.line: There was a lot of friction
between us + the "rookies" +
eventually the company was
mixed up. There was personal
friction with Sgt. Junett{?} or
"tangle eye". Despite all
the lectures about earning ratings
we saw Sgts. on our return
who weren't in the Co. when
we departed. There were some
poor ratings some of which
are still with us. Namely
Rosencranz, Scala, + Hurley{?}
The first furlough was in
November 42. 12 days beginning
the 15th. Furloughs are fine
but leaving is not. I also
got a 3[-]day pass for Xmas.
The Captain gave it to me
15 minutes after he ate me out
for lying about the bed check
to protect T/41 Schumaker. Said
lie also may or may not have
been the cause of Heam making
S/Sgt instead of me. Bo Bo said
yes. I think Heam was the
Captain's pick. I was the only one
of the boys home Xmas 42.
Dec 29 I had my first date
with the preacher's daughter and
soon developed a strong liking for
Camp Chaffee. One month later
to the day[,] we found out we
were moving to Camp Crowder, Mo.
During the month Frank2 went
to Ft. Knox, we had the M. J. P.3
tests, Norris went to 2nd army
H. Q. + Heam to O. C. S. + I made

footnotes.note: 1. T/4: Technician Fourth Grade
2. The author's elder brother
3. Military Judgement Proficiency

page.line: S/Sgt. Feb. 9 we left with
D-23d + moved to Crowder, Mo.
It was hot and dusty. Next day
was cold + spitting snow +
my morale hit an all[-]time
low. We got it figured out
that the glaciers brought
the rocks to Mo.[,] but don't
know how come they melted.
Someone suggested maybe they
went back for another load.
We all hated Crowder. Major
Hall, "Cotton Top", + Col. Coe
were the chief sources of
our trouble + be dad
gummed if 2nd army H. Q.
wasn't next door. We'd have
calisthenics till Cotton Top
gave out watching us. The
field problems of Chaffee gave
way to Bivouacs + Hikes [[sic]] in
the rocks. Long will I remember
the March Bivouac + Cotton
Top Saluting [[sic]] with his crooked
stick. 12 miles a day hike +
25 miles once a week. Dog fights among
some of them. Dress up on
a string + fire drills at
night. Sonny[? Sammy?] Strait asked
about string one night + Sgt.
Wolfe "The Romp{? Ramp?}" kept us
out 30 minutes trying to
find the guilty person. The
only breaks in the grind
were week ends [[sic]] in Okla.
with Sgt. Laurie{?}, some
at home + a couple in
Ft. Smith + Miami. Second
Furlough [[sic]] was March 1st
for 10 days. The 2nd Army
M. J. P. tests were killers.
Crowder + Cotton Top would
drive any sane man crazy. May
18 we left for a Pof. E.{?} +
got as far as Joplin {MO?} +
were stopped by high water.
Back to Crowder the most
disgusted bunch of men
alive + stayed 1 month.
About 20 of us were disgusted
enough to turn in our
stripes. We once set a
date even. Bo Bo gave
Johnston + I a week to
get on the ball[,] + the
Romp + I had a run in.
June 13 - 43[,] I was home for
the last time before embarking
+ June 18 we left for N. Y.
Pof. E. We went to Camp
Kilmer, N. J. We were there
till July 21st. Doing little
+ wanting to do less. Had
my first visit to the big city
+ Coney Island + met an Arkie1
+ his girlfriend + family + girl[-]
friend's girlfriend. There was
a screwed up parade July 4th.
From Kilmer we crossed country
to Camp Anza, California
+ after 3 days in circles
+ over the "ship side" we
took our final overseas
exam (a short arm) +
on Aug 1 - 43 we boarded
the U. S. A. T. Uruguay1.
We got on first to get
the "choice quarters" as
Bo Bo called them. We got
Area 20 on "D" deck + below
water line. After 3 days
I was moved to a room on "B"
deck with 5 others + 6 truck
drivers. Area 20 was totally
lacking ventilation + I still
marvel no one died. The
trip was monotonous + we
were crowded on the "Sardine
Sea Palace" as the name
implies. We went unescorted
to Hobart, Tasmania. Black
out at night. We hit Hobart Aug
23 + left the following day.

footnotes.note: 1. U. S. A. T. (United States Army Transport, AKA U.S.S.) Uruguay. A history of the ship is provided at: http://www.moore-mccormack.com/SS-Uruguay-1938/SS-Uruguay-Timeline.htm; additional details at https://oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/c8dv1kns/entire_text/

page.line: We had shore leave in Hobart.
From there on {ring} making was
the rage. We hit
Fremantle, Australia on Aug. 29
+ left 30th with U. S. A. T.
Brazil + Hermitage. After
that we were told definitely
we'd come to India. We
docked in Bombay Sept. 12th
+ got off 13th. We proceeded
by rail to a British
rest camp at Deolali. Opinions of
British rations were soon
formed + unaltered. We left
there by rail Sept. 20th having
gotten on the train "promptly"
at 8 the night before. All
across India to Calcutta
we saw starvation,
monkeys, naked kids, swarms
of beggars, + incessant nut
scratching. We got up at 6 A.M.
to be sure to be ready to
change to a narrow gauge
R. R. near Calcutta + then
sat + sweated + drove beggars
away till 4 P.M. Throughout
the trip we ate "Service Biscuits"[,]
tea, + corned mutton + slept
like a huge litter of pups
beneath an umbrella of
mosquitos. Were parked
more than we ran. Another
rest camp at {Druby} + a
"Hot Meal" + concrete bunks.
Bo Bo got lost on the way
there from the town.
Distance 3 blocks.
Form {Druby} we rod a river
boat for "30 hours" which
is 3 days in my language.
The company occapied [[occupied]] an area
of 12 feet x 80 feet. We sat
on the floor + slept on the
floor[--]all but the last 10
men to lay down who didn't
have a place to lay. On one
occasion I got sick at my belly
+ didn't have room to get
out to erp[,] so I erped in
my own "bed" then mopped
it up with a paper + lay
back down in it. After
that we got up at 5 A. M. to
get off at 10. Another
train ride of 1 day + 2 nights.
During the day we put on
our packs at 2:45 to get
off at 3. We got off at
9 the following morning at
our present location, Margarita [[Margherita]].
We're in a "temporary area"
for a week. This is no. 3
+ here[']s the beginning of
the much[-]discussed diary.
Oct 15 The Hebrew nailed
me soon after breakfast to
haul 6 loads of gravel (Washed).
We waited till mid-morning
for the truck to be started.
Made a trip to the Engineers
to get a permit for the gravel.
After visiting 2 pits[,] we
returned to Harvey + got 2
loads at once (Unwashed).
{Henry} got the truck stuck
in the driveway and we
had to unload there. After
noon he finally got out + the
truck was taken by Frisco
to get supplies + by {Daldorf}
for rations. We hauled no
more gravel + the one load
sank beneath the mud +
vanished. Deposited $60
with finance officer. {Yambro}
got ate out for putting yeast in
the hop mixture + Fauzon
was urged to shave by Ramp.
Oct 16 The Hebrew told me
the truck was taken for the
A. M.[,] but to start hauling at
1 P. M. sharp. I gold bricked1
all morning at the brush pile.
At 1 P. M. I had my detail

footnotes.note: 1. gold brick: to shirk one's responsibility; to do less work than one is able; to invent excuses to avoid a task

page.line: ready but the truck was on
another mission. At 1:30 it
returned + left for salvage.
At 2[,] my detail was aroused
to help Johnston move the
latrine + then he remembered
I was to report to the Field
Marshal at 1. Fields was
sent up by the field marshal
to inquire why I wasn't there.
He returned with the word
that Johnston was using the
{man} + I came to my tent
+ stayed. Muller took over
the bakery + is {rared} back
so far I can't figure out
how he maintains his
equilibrium.
Oct 17 Sunday I was glad
when I heard the bugle[,] for
I figured we'd rest up. I
saw my mistake[,] however[,]
when assembly was sounded
at 6:45. Was going up the
path griping about being
hooked for the 15 min. + the
field marshal heard +
{mounted} me. He {mounted}
again when I asked for
half a day off. Everyone
is griping. The bulldozer
moved some stumps + {Laum}
+ I are working on a jobs schedule.
Oct 18 The day[']s work was
uneventful but this is
a day to be long re-
membered. Our "B" bags
came. They've been
coming every day for 3
weeks. Got a letter from
home + they still don't
know where I am. Found
a leech on my stomach.
{Lumer} burnt him off +
just as I never expected[,]
didn't burn me. {Fawzon}
got his head {peeled} and is
saying I cut it to keep
the Hebrew off {Veronie}.
Oct 19 Put a locust in
{Yambrick[']s} net last night
and he's been playing Sherlock
all day trying to find the
guilty person. Stayed in
my tent this morning + wrote
letters. Had a feeling I'd best
go to the brush pile
afternoon[,] so I did + Presley
caught Polock in his
tent. Wintz gave me a "desk".
Oct 20 Polock + {Brenhoff}
are getting stuck $40 each
for shooting off rifles while
on guard. The morning I spent
reading down at "{Gulk's} Mon-
astery"[,] however[,] I was stricken
with remorse afternoon and
hauled rocks for seepage
pit. Scattergood made a
spirited declaration about
the company fund. Schu-
maker said he figured an
officer would get a new car
with it + Presley heard him.
The fund is going to be
dissolved + cigarettes bought
with it given away.
Bug show on bricks.{?}
Oct 21 The field marshal
gave me the detail of building
a walk from pump to Bkry [Bakery].
Wilkerson, Maier, Rosy, Curtis
Soriano in morning +
Tex, Kappel, + {Maynerd} P. M.
Wilkerson + I sawed a
nail + the saw was out
of order after that. We
both know it sounded
like a nail but didn't
think a nail was ever
seen in India before the
U. S. Army came. Still can't
figure how one got in
the middle of a tree. We're
working later now + started
forming in platoons to go to
work. Barely time for a bath
before chow + am doing laundry
now by the fire light.
Oct 22 Same old grind at the
brush pile. Sawed wood in
the morning. Maynerd refiled
saw but drags are long
+ it still don't cut. Afternoon
I stayed here + talked to
Johnston a while. Then I
went to brush pile + Bruno
Primm + I made out list
for tomorrow's baking. We
got Jones all wound up about
Yambrick. Then we sat down
+ listened to him unwind
for about an hour. Johnston
says 2 platoons may leave.
Oct 23 My platoon was
baking all day. The
Hebrew was our constant
companion until the
bread started coming out
looking good. Then he left.
Bread all looked good
+ Presley + Bo Bo were
both pleased. Bo Bo had
covers made for proof rack.
They were 2 inches short so
I cut the holes bigger to
let them drop. He had a
fit first. Then he looked
+ decided it a good deed.
Oct 24 Sunday and we
worked again but baking
on Sunday doesn't gripe us
like fighting the brush
pile. Hear a rumor that 1st
+ 4th Ptns will leave. Tex +
Tyler almost had a fight in
mess hall. Bo Bo lost
his canteen cup. Jew had
us sprinkling lime after dark.
Pete put big bug on Johnston.
Oct 25 Scattergood told me to
move equipment across ditch
but {Gulck} took all the men
+ as I can't lift an oven alone[,] I
went over to the stump + sat
all morning. Lots of native
music across the river. My
platoon got the P. M. off + I
caught up on my writing. Got
a letter from Mary Jo + it is
the first from anyone saying they've
heard I'm in India. Schumaker
didn't fall out[,] so he's digging
a latrine hole.
Oct 26 The field marshal didn't know
Schumaker was digging the hole for
punishment[,] so he detailed 5 men
to help him. Boy will Bo Bo throw
a fit! Had a walk building
detail all day. Afternoon I found
a stone (5 lbs) + sharpened knives.
The native who lost the stone will
hunt a long time as I'm keeping it.
After supper I went to the mess
hall to write Jo1 a letter + Tex
was sitting next to me[,] so I had a
heck of a time concentrating.
Oct 27 Same old story over at
the new area. Mess equipment is
being moved. Got a pair of
ingrown whiskers + had to
get Salhoff to remove them.
Put up a clothes rack in
our basha2. Sure would like to
know how to spell that word.
Also would like to know where
to get some hinges for the
footlocker I'm Building. Now
I'm gonna borrow M. {Smithe}
foot medicine + go to bed

footnotes.note: 1. Jo Phillips: the author's mother
2. basha: "an Assamese hut typically made of bamboo and grass" (https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/basha)

page.line: Oct 28 McGillivany got
fired off of the job building
a roof over lister bag1. Also
got eat out for building fire near
basha. 1st Platoon moved.
Got stump out finally. Hebrew
had a fit because I never
fell my platoon in with the
company. The last three times
I tried[,] no one but me fell in.
Seems like I can't win. Still[,]
I consider the source + will sleep OK.
Oct 29 After working toward that end
for 29 days[,] we finally moved into
our new {area}. I'm now in a basha
with Wolfe, Heft, Johnston, Tyler,
Muller, and {De Fontes}. It is a sight
dryer than the tents + we have
a gasoline lantern. Almost had a
fight with Daldorf at noon. He didn't

footnotes.note: 1. Lister bag (usually capitalized): "a canvas water bag used especially for supplying military troops with chemically purified drinking water" (https://www.merriam-webster.com/medical/Lister%20bag)

page.line: like my sense of humor. I told him to
figure out what he was going to do
about it whereas he decided to forget
it. So will I. Levine mounted Johnston
about saw head.
Oct 30 Spent the whole day
over in the old area policing up
and turning in the charpoys1.
We also swiped a truck[-]
load of bricks. A "gook"
wanted us to sign for it[,] but
we did not. Presley has a
meeting of second platoon N. C. O.'s2.
Oct 31 My platoon baked today. It
was the first day in the new
temporary bakery[,] and of course
it was a messed up deal. The
ovens were two hours late
being set up and then Bo Bo
had to have them washed

footnotes.note: 1. charpoy: a bed used especially in India consisting of a frame strung with tapes or light rope
2. N.C.O.: Non-commissioned officer.

page.line: before we could start. The
sponges got plenty old[,] but I
presume Bo Bo liked the sparkling
oven surfaces. Finished up at
about 10 P. M. Johnston + I went
visiting late. He had an over[-]
dose of bamboo juice + among
other things[,] he fell off the bridge.
No harm done.
Nov. 1 Got paid today. Well
good! Gave Muller my share
of Rupees for the anteroom
we're having built. Baked 66
{runs}[,] which is a record to-date
but wait till tomorrow. 86
maybe. First letter from home
saying they know where I am.
Got our Xmas cards today.
Drawing by Primm + mimeo[-]
graph on V-mail forms.
Got Wentz excited over {duck} box.
Nov 2 The most hectic day since
the river boat and more disgusting
because this was unnecessary.
Fast schedule for 84 doughs.
Bo Bo was gawking around
last night and got us an hour
late. Also he had salt added
+ cut the yeast. The stuff didn't
move in the boxes + the schedule
appeared to be way off. Finished
at 11 instead of 5. Presley was on
me about men smoking + on Roscoe.
Nov 3 Ran the 84 doughs today
+ on time. Everyone was well
pleased on that count. Muller +
I tried to reason with Bo Bo
that the men were putting in too
much time + not having any
for themselves. His head like
his {rear} is pretty fat + it
never soaked through. However
2 platoons will do the baking
hereafter + I got half a day off
for my platoon tomorrow. The
chief remark that got him
was the one about gooks brushing
the men[']s teeth for them.
Nov 4th Flipped a coin with James
L. to see who got the first shift next
week. He did. In the morning
we cleared up some scrap lumber
+ got the afternoon off. Made some
bamboo hangers + got my clothes
out of my bag + hung up. Addressed
all my Xmas cards and put
my homemade locker up on the wall
making it a cabinet + no longer a locker.
Bruno got out of the hospital.
Also got my wicker chair.
Nov 5 Cleared brush by the duck
pen in the A. M. P. M. Bruno's +
{Premmer}'s sections worked around
bashas and Pete + his boys
dug the latrine hole by the
river deeper. Pete went to sleep +
I removed his bracelet + he didn't
wake up. I still have it. Threw
rocks across river with sling.
Nov 6 Same old routine. Clear
weeds in the morning + work
around bashas afternoon.
Ran out of tooth powder and
have resorted to soda. Laurie
bought me a G. Knife. Cleaned
rifle for a change. Tried to
give {Laurie} torn rupee + he
refused it despite the fact
that it came from {orderly}
room. Ante room completed.
Nov 7 Sunday and for the first
time since I've been here in India
I went to church. Services over at
20th Gen. Hosp. My ptn. baked
afternoon + Johnston's in A. M.
He had corn meal in the {field
bread} + things in general were in
a mess. Tried to turn in his
stripes but don't think they took them.
Nov 8 Johnston is still S/Sgt + his
ptn. was on schedule today. Two
sponges were mixed at 8 but we
took them young and finished shortly
after 8 P. M. Everyone got two quarts
of Indian Beer. I sold mine to
{D'Ettore}. A plan to put calves in
officers quarters is being talked up.
When the beer is gone[,] so will the
plan be. Possibly not.
Gave {Murzyn} 1st Class rimming [[reaming]].

margin.line: After beer was gone[,] boys drank 6 gallons

page.line: Nov 9 Everything was running well in
the bakery. In fact[,] Scattergood said
so himself. First civil word since
the argument. Suddenly I heard a
holler "Jesus Christ"[.] I looked
around + saw Smoot + Heslin
holding a sponge can + dough
strung from it + out of sight
behind the table. I followed it down
+ beheld a whole dough in the
floor. Then I was it start
working in the middle and
suddenly {Farnson} emerged, head
covered with dough. He + {Compfort}
lifted the back end of can before
front end was on bench + dumped
dough on floor. Then he rushed
under to catch the dough + got
it wrapped around his {neck}.
The gang is giving us the laugh
and I don't blame them. Never saw
anything like it. Marin is T/51 + moved
into my platoon. Compfort goes out.
Nov 10 While I was peacefully
writing a letter[,] we had our 2nd
air raid alarm. Dropped everything
+ grabbed Steel + gas mask + hit
the air raid shelter + nothing happened.
174,936th dry run since I got in
C96 alias 111th[.] Baked off one oven[-]
load of raisin bread + Lewis
immediately took it to the kitchen
so it wouldn't be stolen. Ferraro
caught a 6 lb. fish from the river
while he was detailed to dust
out flour sacks.
Nov 11th General Arrowsmith visited
the bakery. Lt. Presley got excited +
introduced him to Bo Bo as Lt.
Bo Bo wanted to hurry + shake

footnotes.note: 1. T/5: Technician fifth grade

page.line: hands with him so he'd have
something to write home to Harriet
but he also wanted to salute him
from a halt. He had up so much
momentum that when he halted his
feet[,] his body kept going. I thought
he was going to fall on his face. If
I were as scared of higher rank as
my officers[,] I'd be a nervous wreck.
At supper a Lt. Col. was visiting +
Tyler (Mess Sgt.) had on his white
clothes + was waiting table like a
D. R. O.1 All was going well + Bo Bo
was happy though ill at ease for fear
one of us would do something irregular.
I did. I sounded off to Tyler "Sgt. Tyler,
if you'd get some black stripes on that
white rig[,] they'll really show up." He
turned 6 colors + Bo Bo 7. He's still
purple. The Col. isn't so dumb he thinks
we always put on the dog like that.

footnotes.note: 1. D. R. O.: Dining Room Orderly

page.line: Nov. 12 Bo Bo swiped the big fly
spray out of our Basha. Gilbert Smith
got a detail putting axe heads on handles.
Just to hear Bo Bo gripe he put a head
on each end of one handle. We got a
table in our ante-room. Something got
into the chicks after dark + the ramp
wanted me to go shoot it. Be
damned if I'll clean a rifle just to
save the life of a duck that will
soon be eaten anyway but I did go
to see what it was. Found nothing.
Nov. 13 Sgt. Heft is pretty mad because
I got Maier from him as he is
one of the best bakers + I have 1/2
of all the bakers already. I laid out
my equipment to write a letter + then
went to brush my teeth. I came back
+ the Field Marshal was in my chair
"helping" Heft figure a schedule. I
knew it would be a long process so
came back in 2 hrs + Tex was
here. He asked me if Compfort was as good
a bench hand as Maier. I reared back
+ laughed aloud. Heft blew his top
+ I laughed the louder. Fact is Lt. {Gulck}
gave me Maier + kept {Uvonnie} because
{Uvonnie} is his blue[-]eyed boy. It's no
fault of mine the field marshall would
rather keep the one he likes than the
one he needs. Tyler sounded off at
{Ganger}. He'll do well to live the
duration in India if he takes care of
himself + the only way for him to take
care of himself in a fight is stay out of it.
3 up + 1 down will get a man into trouble
for hitting the owner but won't make
the beating less thorough.
Nov 14 Heft had a hectic A. M.
3 lbs. of sugar in {fried} dough +
4 too many sponges. Got a report on
the day's discrepancies from Gilbert
who is always more than glad to do so.
Scala got a tit caught in a sponge
can + has it taped up. Starkey is
making home brew + the Lts. are
trying to catch him. {Yambrick's}
men got a dough in the floor + he
was pretty hot. Next dough he {w?}
up to pull dough out of can + got
hit in head by same. Knocked him
down + that cooled him off.
Nov 15Johnston + I sent about 50 fellows to
sign payroll in supply room. De Fontes
got tired smoking them out + swarmed out
upon Johnston. Bo Bo called me to the
officers' Qtrs. + gave me a fatherly
talk on "attitude". Same was none
improved by the information that
some Sgt. had squawked on me.
Bo Bo doesn't realize that if N. C. O.s were
in sympathy with officers they'd be
classed as low in the minds of the
men. Besides that it would take 5
N. C. O.s to please the 5 officers + then
each one would displease 4 officers +
all them together would outrank the
one he did please. I still don't see
that a man can win. Bo Bo said
it wasn't fair to criticize officers
when they were not present whereas
I told him he was present in mess
hall Nov. 3rd. Next he said if I
had anything in mind that the
officers should do different[,] the
thing to do was tell them. I took
him at his word + named off
several including {handing} out
the Tech. Sgt. + putting a stop
to the {bricking}. I likewise told
him the Sgt. who squealed on me was
no doubt griping as much as I was[,] the
difference being I never told on him.
I have heard Muller gripe lately.
I was surprised that he was being a
pretty decent fellow lately. Now I
see that he's still his old self +
{Hefty} is a "possible" too.
Nov 16 Wolfe, Scattergood, Field Marshal,
Presley + Heft were all in Bkry.
bright + early to end cracks in
Field head. F. M. built a wood
fire in proof rack + it was too
hot. Tex put a thermometer in it
+ it hit the top. Some say the
reason it (Bread) busted worse
than ever before was because
the proof rack was only 350Â°
+ should be 450 for baking
purposes. Gilbert Smith got
stranded in Latrine without paper
+ I came to his rescue. Bo Bo
came in + found me talking to
him + that probably didn't raise
his opinion of my attitude.
Nov 17 Now I'm stricken with remorse
for what I wrote about Muller the 15th
but then[,] he'll never know it unless
he reads my diary + if he does that
he likely is guilty of being the
stool pigeon. And speaking of the
past[,] I forgot to put down an incident
a week ago. Tex made some
cinnamon rolls + Bo Bo was
eating him out because they were
too heavy. While he was doing
the eating out he devoured 7
rolls + waddled off. From the
depth of his footprints[,] I'd say
the rolls were heavy. For a
week[,] the Ramp, {Loreno}, + Tex have
been chasing the "sacred" cows.
Finally they caught one + had it
butchered last night. {Comhoff}
ordered that no steaks be cut off
+ fried. Then Bo Bo had one about
as big as a fatigue hat fried
for himself. Shortly after that[,]
Levine tried the same + Bo Bo
chased him out without
hesitation. This particularly irked
the Hebrew as Tex + {Loreno} had one
for themselves. The Field Marshal
was drooling too[,] but couldn't
throw his rank on anyone but
Gook Macano + that still left
the vacuum in his belly.
He tried to get his mind off it
by going out + pitching horse[-]
shoes but cows kept going
by + he looked upon each one
with tearful eye. Then the Ramp
asked Bo Bo how about steaks
for all the men. Reply[:] "Sgt.[,] the
meat is just too tough for steaks"[,]
then he hauled out for the kitchen
to see how his was coming.
The Hebrew kept muttering in his head
+ Bo Bo finally got too mad to eat.
Then he made life so miserable for
the Hebrew that he didn't eat any
supper. He should keep that up
for a while--say 3 months.
At supper we had hamburger.
Comhoff says 7 cows + steaks at
any hour from 6 A. M. to midnight
next time. Maybe the cows are
sacred + this is the curse that
comes from slaughtering them.
Heft's boys left yeast out of field
bread + it looked like wheat cakes.
They're so thin that when they
threw some in for the ducks
they couldn't see the ones that
landed edgeways + someone jumped
at the conclusion even the ducks wouldn't
eat the stuff. Duration + 6 months
+ then I'll go so far back in the
hills I'll never see a soldier +
where one as big as Bo Bo
couldn't get between the trees.
Nov 18 The officers are back on
normal rations again today.
Levine has probably been reading "The
life of Ghandi". Got sand out of
fire bucket + shined mess gear in
A. M. Also got truck + pulled some
stumps around basha. Nothing
more unusual afternoon than Ramp
chasing butterflies. He says there
was once a day when a fellow
would {get} a goofy discharge for
such things. However[,] in this company
no one could be goofy enough to
get discharged though he might
get drafted for O. C. S. Even
Bernhoff knows enough to eat.
Nov 14 Big doings today. Karlewski got
caught swiping jam out of the
kitchen. My boys got two cans a
week ago but the difference is
they ate the stuff leaving no
evidence. Pollock was arrested.
Gouger got mad + went into the
kitchen to tell Tyler off. The Ramp
heard him + he was also arrested
+ both are under guard; Schumaker.
Gouger is a good Sgt. when he wants to
be[,] but will make a poor private. If
he isn't busted he should be as he's
had occasion to be busted before
+ has been given another chance. Same
goes for Pollock. I don't blame either of
them though... not Gouger at least.
He, like a lot of the rest of us[,] is fed
up with boy scout activities. The
whole thing goes back to lack of
leadership which has existed since
Norris left. Bo Bo + other 90[-]day
wonders[,] who wouldn't make good
Pfc's[,]1 get by in the states where
lots of brass backs them up[,] but
this is different. And two or three
mixed in with some officers can
get by[,] but 5 of a kind trying to
run a company is a sad sack. I'm
not too sure the company won't {run}
them in the end. Someone put a
picture of a bulldog wearing Top Sgt's
stripes on the bulletin board. He
thinks I did it. I guess Koncak.

footnotes.note: Pfc: Private First Class

page.line: Took the company to the laundry for
a talk on sex morality. A good
look at native women in the
daylight would have been quicker,
more impressive, more effective, +
above all something different. I've
heard the sad facts the Major
dwelled upon at least 50 times.
Twister knocked down one of Louis'
palm trees. We told him Henry hit
it with the truck + he had a fit.
Nov 20 Goldbricked in A. M. again.
Tinkered around with post auger
trying to develop a muffler for
mixers. Got Ferraro to shave the
head. Afternoon off. Was over
to Landmon's shack and he jokingly
asked me if I wanted to finish a
letter for him. I surprised him +
did just that. It was to his {N. J.} gal
+ I spread it on right thick.
Then he surprised me by signing
his name to it + mailing. Says
it's better than he could have
written. Heard some sputtering +
muffled sounds up in edge of
ball field after dark when I went
up to give Fisher his pencil. It
turned out to be McKee on a
crying drunk. The boys poured
approx. 100 gallons of water over
him. Good thing he can swim.
Nov 21 Gouger, who is still Sgt, called
me at 5 A. M. Boys were going strong on
the field bread and Seabiscuit was
{fanning} over doors and rattling
can lids as early as 2 A. M. He
used a young fence post
to dock field bread + got irons
put a couple of places they
didn't belong. I honestly
wonder if he thinks he's helping
us[,] or[,] if since he knows we'll
get the job done[,] he wants to appear
to be taking over to feather his
own cap. If the first is the
case[,] he is laboring under a false
impression. Hallucination maybe.
If it's a star in his own crown
he's after[,] it will work beautifully.
All you got to do is point out a
couple of your worthy deeds to
Bo Bo + he thinks you're on
the ball or sucking in + either
one pleases him. On the
other hand[,] you do your duty a
month + he doesn't see it but
if someone points out where you
slipped once[,] he believes it
without investigation. For
example my attitude. Both
platoons last week had men in
them who screwed up intentionally
'cause no one was shadowing them.
My platoon is the only one which
can be trusted to a man + Bo Bo
would see it if he looked but
instead he takes the word of Sgt.
?? that our attitude is off and
doesn't consider that if our attitude
was as bad as reported the work
would match it. Damn the
fatuous five + their feeble
following. Cornhoff is the only
one who doesn't deserve to have
his rear kicked till his nose
bleeds + he's as useless to the
U. S. Army as Eleanor1. We can
stand him because he doesn't
make any pretense. Dug mufflers
behind mixers + did 47 push-ups.

footnotes.note: 1. Eleanor: Presumably the First Lady at the time, Eleanor Roosevelt.

page.line: Nov 22 Tex heard such favorable
reports of the letter I wrote for Landmon
that he wanted me to write to Dottie for
him. My writing doesn't resemble his
so I wrote her with my left hand
+ told her that I (Tex) got hit in
the elbow with a horse shoe
+ had had my arm in a sling
for a week. I'll get him in a jam
+ then let him try to wiggle out.
No excitement other than Petrenak
shooting at a cat which was
trying to catch a duck. He
inflicted quite a severe wound
in the fence [in] back of the cat.
Nov 23 We ran raisin bread all
day today so the boys can have it
for Thanksgiving. Schumaker figured
out a "theme song" for Seabiscuit.
It is the same tune that accompanies

margin.line: {Tony} dug up lizard eggs + we put them in a bucket.

page.line: the sound of hoof beats when the
Lone Ranger comes on the air.
At every break he says "back to the
ovens", ["]back to the bench["], ["]out by
the irons"[,] etc. Wilson says he's
afraid he'll lock himself up inside
of an oven. Some Colonels visited the
area + Ramp told Bo Bo he knew
one when he was a 2nd Lt. + has
Bo Bo behaving a lot of bunk
about how he's taken the credit
for improved area etc. Bo Bo would
give his right leg for what he
believes to be Wolfe's "suction".
Fact is[,] Ramp never saw {Fairhather} before.
Nov 24 Put burlaps over bunk.
First rain since we moved
into grass shack + it leaks faster
than it rains outside. Spent some
time trying to find dry spot to write.
After skipping a day[,] the yeast was
no good + bread looks like
crackers. 1st run that is. The hay
fever bothered me so bad in A. M.
that I had to take out. Tyler
put S. {Halves} over bunks to
{trim} water.
Nov 25 Thanksgiving + we had
Turkey, c. berry sauce, dressing,
salad, punch, coffee, spuds,
cake, pie + a few other things. Far
better feed than I thought possible
in India. 1st Platoon is leaving so
I got a book + am getting civilian
addresses of all the boys while the
Co. is together. The letter I wrote
giving my opinion of each + every
officer without cramping my
style evidently went thru the
office O. K. On the other hand[,] they
may pass it around for a few
days before sending it on or back.
I'm fixing to write the story of
the company from the time Bruno
+ I got in it for him. Got his
notes in order after some difficulty.
Played two games of H[[orse]]shoes with
Maynerd + skunked him. Then he
beat me one + I beat him one. I
have sworn to cease trying my
sunny disposition by playing that
game as I invariably blow up
after a couple or three good games.
Same happened today when Johnston [+]
I played again. Dad gummit.
Weighed 175. Record to date.
Nov 26 Laurie woke me up at 4 A. M. to
call my platoon. I got up, sprinkled
the grass closer to the door than
I should have, told him to call
them + went back to bed. The field
bread popped open + 2 ovens had all
British flour + were thrown back +
made up again. Johnston's platoon only
worked 3 hrs. + then quit to start packing.
Afternoon Laurie + I went down to
the river[,] which I was tryin to throw
a rock across with my sling. The
string broke + I threw the pocket
+ other string halfway across.
That stopped that so I came to the
shack + wrote on Bruno's Co.
story for a while. After supper
Laurie came over + wanted me to
go to the party. The officers
never put a stop to the still
though they think they have. It
is in the island in the middle
of the river + several gallons were
brought over + about half the 1st
platoon got sick in the course of
their farewell blowout. I was
pretty busy helping one to bed,
another up to vomit, another to
find the door[,] etc. Finally as I left
nowhere near sick[,] I gave {Kendrat} a
good start. He went out the door just
ahead of me. I barged out "Loookout[,]
I've gotta erp." He stepped aside to
give me plenty of room. I humped
up my back + chased him half a
quarter. The thought he was in
imminent danger of being sprayed.
He was sure surprised when I commenced
laughing.
Nov 27 The guard woke me at 5 but
I got up at breakfast. There was an
unusually crummy {beggar} down
to the bakery. 1st Platoon left
+ though it didn't seem at all
touching like it would have in
the states[,] I'll miss Old Johnston.
He's the only S/Sgt. I care much
about as he's the only one who
shares my opinion of most of
the company doings. {Redenbaur}
moved into "Dumpy's Dump" +
I finished Bruno's company story.
Nov 28 Planned to sleep all A.M.[,] but ducks
were having mass athletics by our
door + woke me up. Went to church in
new building + got back ahead of {Hineman}
though he got the first ride. Turner
shaved my head afternoon + {Landmon} +
I took a stroll down the river.
Bo Bo is still talking to Phelps
about slipping + getting off schedule.
He's remembered that remark now
for 24 days. A {re???} for him +
I feel honored to've made such a
lasting impression on our C. O.
Nov 24 Went on sick call with the
hay fever. The Captain (Pill {Roller})
did as much as I expected, gave
me a prescription + on it[,] among
other things[,] were the words "use
as directed." He gave me no directions.
The pharmacist put the concoction
in a bottle, seemed appalled that I
didn't already have a dropper,
grudgingly gave me one, wrote
"use as directed" on the bottle, +
since he didn't know he sent me
back to Captain who may have
sent me to the pharmacist with
the vague directions for the same
reason. The captain had gone + his
no. 1 boy (Pfc.) advised me to use
the nose drops "when your nose is
stopped up". I will. Found 3 snake
eggs to add to the lizard eggs.
Watched an elephant launch some
boats. Pulled bamboo from back
of {Lurie's} Basha with truck + under
the able leadership of the Ramp.
Primm drew two cards. One
for me to send Frank1 for his B.day +
the other to send Mr. + Mrs. {Leinenger}.
Nov 30 Pay day again. They didn't
blow the bugle yet Scattergood seemed
astounded that I didn't make it down
there along with a couple of Staffs
who were there beforehand. I had to
wait till last but 30 minutes isn't bad
when you've waited 30 days already.
Got a big kick out of standing + watching
the different half[-]hearted and haphazard
salutes. Turner's took the prize. He
wore the same expression he wears when

footnotes.note: 1. The author's elder brother.

page.line: he's molding bread and that[,] in turn[,]
is the same expression a woman wears
when cleaning cat crap off a rug.
Bo Bo has a running fit if an E. M. is seen
carrying a piece of lumber as big as a
bar of soap away from the pile but today
he had Wentz build a door casing for
the officers['] Basha, Sloppy Bottoms,
that looked like an arch to put across
a highway. Also[,] he was griping about
2 or 3 men working around the bashas but
you should see him {rare} back when
some brass comments favorably on the
appearance.
Dec 1 When we moved over to this
area + even before that[,] the Field
Marshal had the boys not cut
the weeds, but scoop grass + all
off leaving dirt to become India's
leading mud hole when the
monsoons come. The alleged
reason was that mosquitos abound in
grass. Today we started putting sod
down. No doubt the mosquitos will
take the first project as a hint
they're not wanted + will be too
independent to come back. The report
came in today that the Japs used gas
at Chunking. Field Marshal issued
order for boys baking to bring masks
to bakery. If we're gassed[,] the quickest
+ only possible way it could brought
is by plane. We get the air alarm
at least 15 minutes early. Then the
boys have time to go to bashas +
get steel + rifle. It looks to me
like they could get their masks at
the same time but the Field Marshal
outranks me so evidently I'm
mistaken. This A. M. I heard the
sound of something that sounded like
a bull to me[,] but it was over the
bank of the river where no bull
would go. I told Mora (Guard) to
bring his rifle + maybe we'll find
something to shoot. It was an
elephant + had 3 natives on his back.
Dec 2 Brewer died today. I first
met him on the train en route
to A. I. B. from Camp Lee. He'd
been with me ever since + he had
been with me longer than any
man in the company. Now I'm the
only one of the original 9 who came
from Lee. Only 4 of the 9 are here now[:]
Bruno, Timmy, Muller, + I. Was
over to him 3 days ago + he
seemed in pretty good spirits[,] but I
told Pete he'd never get well. Maier[,]
Ramp + I almost chased a "Sacred
cow" in the river. We has her
balancing on the edge + if Wolfe had
only pushed when I yelled[,] there
would have been a mighty splash.
It was my ambition to be able to
go back to the States saying I'd eaten
a steak off a sacred cow from the
day I found I was coming to India.
That ambition was fulfilled Nov 11
but now I want to commit a
greater outrage + chase one into
the river. The time will come.
The Field Marshal has evidently come
to the conclusion that what this
company needs is fuller utilization of
manpower. Today one man was
driving two trucks. {Utter} would
drive the big truck up to be loaded
with dirt. Then walk + get the
weapons carrier + take it up to
be filled with sod. Then walk
over to the big truck + drive it down
to be unloaded etc. For such a
display of initiative The Field Marshal
should be decorated but I guess mention
in this book is all he'll get.
The Mess Sgt. is lamenting in a loud
voice. There was a Chinaman here
today buying cigarettes. He couldn't
speak or understand a word of English.
He was up to the kitchen dealing with
Tyler. Bo Bo rimmed Tyler severely
for having him around. Tyler said
he couldn't help it whereas Bo Bo
said "The Chinaman told me you told
him to come." Tyler can't figure out
how he told Bo Bo anything when he
doesn't speak English. He even suspects
our C. O. of stretching the truth[,] but to
quote him[,] "What's a fellow gonna do[?]"
It beats me.
Dec 3 What a cheerful day! Early
this morning there was a wreck on
the Margarita Bridge. The bridge is
primarily a R. R. bridge but it
has been floored + used by trucks
+ trains alike. It works pretty good as
a rule[,] but this morning both were
trying to use it at the same time.
A train met 6 trucks on it. The
driver of the first truck spotted the
train + tried to beat it. He just
got off + the train hit his truck
on the rear end. He wasn't hurt. The
next 5 were all piled up. Motors +
other parts flew in all directions.
Some of them caught fire + I thought
the trestle would burn down. The
train was loaded with Chinese
Cavalry + one of the trucks was
loaded with Gooks. As best I can
find out[,] the dead were 5 American
soldiers, 22 Goooks, + at least 1
Chinaman. The scrambled Gooks
were all over the bridge, on the
sand bar, + in the river. The
latter were picked up in a few
boats. Bruno + I sat on the bank of
the river + could see it all. This
afternoon we buried Brewer up in
the tea plantation. It was pretty
impressive. The whole company, his
buddies for the duration, stood with
heads uncovered during the prayer,
the Scripture reading, the sounding of
taps, + the firing of the rifles. Some
Indians stood nearby + no doubt thought
it strange procedure. One woman, a
nurse, was present. All around was
green grass + then acre after acre
of tea, beautifully green + smooth.
In the distance was the mountains,
range after range with the snow
caps in the far distance plainly
visible. India is a miserable country
but Earl is buried in a beautiful
though lonely spot. When we came
over[,] no man expected us to all go
back[,] yet each man felt sure he
would. It all helps a man to realize
the insignificance of the individual.
Like the rest[,] I feel certain I'll again set
foot on the U. S. + live a long +
happy life. God willing[,] I shall.
Dec 4 Nothing out of the ordinary happened
till noon. We had spam, mashed
potatoes, + gravy which seemed to me
to be a little better than common.
I sat down + as I put the third
bite in my mouth[,] a husky looking
worm dropped off the ceiling and
landed with a splash flat of [[on]] his
back in the gravy in my mess kit.
After a brief flailing of many legs
he submerged. I took him out +
dumped him in the G. I. can + then[,]
not to be outdone[,] I went back for
seconds + ate them without mishap.
Afternoon Bruno + I went to Margherita
+ looked around. What a dump. Bought
a shoulder patch + pen + will stay
here from now on. The Bar Fly
will never make Tech putting pepper
on sweet potatoes.
Dec 5 After looking forward to
sleeping late this morning for 3 days
+ having chased the ducks away
with such vigor that I knew
they wouldn't come near + wake
me as on last Sunday I woke up
before first call + could not sleep.
First time since we got to India. We
had memorial services in the mess
hall for Brewer. Bo Bo said a few
words. Of course he didn't say the
right words but he was so touched
that for once I felt sorry for him.
I never feel malice toward him
but usually my sympathy runs
to the unfortunate Jr. officers +
E. M. in his command. After
dark the Ramp came by the bakery
and informed me that he'd spotted a
wild bull which we should
be able to chase in the river. As
we pursued the bull around
Sloppy Bottoms (Officers' Quarters)
he suddenly came upon the
fence which Bo Bo had built
around their yard last week.
Bo Bo was right proud of that fence
but today it is in need of repair as
the bull ran right thru it + didn't
even look back to see how big
a gap he left. Eventually we did
get the bull in the river + I got
enough mud on my shoes to
supply 328 mud dobbers the entire
season. The latest event was a
crazy nigger escaped from the hosp.
At about 10 P. M. he came up to our
fire in his pajamas. We called
the hospital but he left before they
came after him + nigger was
still at large at quitting time. If
Bo Bo had been awake I'd have told
him the nigger was last seen
lurking about Sloppy Bottoms +
he wouldn't have slept all night.
Dec 6 Don't know just why but
nothing much happened today. Either
too much yesterday or else something
big coming up tomorrow. Today's
most outstanding event was Utter
ran over my lizard + snake eggs.
That suits me fine. Don't think
they were going to hatch any-
way + this saves me being
outdone. Yesterday[,] anyone but me
would have been highly elated.
I used the nose chops I got Nov. 24
+ then worked on the bench to get
lots of flour dust + thus test
their benefit. No sneeze. But
my wartime motto is "Blessed
is he who expects nothing, for he
shall not be disappointed." And
seldom he is. True again...
Today the hay fever is in
full swing again. There was
a picture show in the mess
hall after supper[:] "Holiday Inn".
Muller has been eating beans
(along with the rest of us) for
the past week + just now by
striking a match at the right
time + place caused a minor
explosion. A new one on me.
Dec 7 When we were clearing
this area[,] we threw a lot of wood
over the river bank. Today Hefty
started pulling it up again to use in
heating irons. Gave Pepper the best
rimming he's had since he got in
this company for not going to work
when told. He was sifting flour and
after the rimming I thought he
would shake the sieve apart.
Wolfe + Seabiscuit wet to Hell's

page.margin: Pete brought me a set of flashlight batteries
page.line: gate where rumors are we'll go
as a platoon soon. Packaged my
Gurkha Knife to send home.
Dec 8 Got the newest Gook to
shine the mess gear. Ball[-]
game afternoon. Yesterday
Salhoff + {Peticenck} were engaged
in a heated argument about which
hole in the new air compressor
was for water + which for
gas. Today they both feel
their knowledge is far beyond
anyone else's in the company.
Dec 9 Began Pete's book "Life with C-96["]1.
followed by half a dozen alias' [[sic]] {aliases?}.
Afternoon Bo Bo came through the bakery
brushing against the boys in the close
places and never spoke to anyone. Not
even to me. Heartbreaking. He hasn't
spoken when it could be helped since

page.line: the heart to heart talk on on Nov. 15. He
told me to tell him anything that was
wrong with the goings on of the Co.
+ then holds it against me because I
didn't compliment him on his able
leadership. Being an obedient E. M.
I told him the truth. I'm a poor mind
reader. After supper (at which I got
De' Fontes told about being so tight about
issuing stuff)[,] Seasbiscuit, Ramp,
De' Fontes + I went scouting for cows
in the jeep. No luck. Someone {stold}
my flashlight out of the bakery
Dec 10 The field Marshal got a desk
+ proudly brought it into the {orderly}
room. When he looked in one of the
drawers he found a swarm of
bees. The desk is now in the
woods opposite the {orderly} room.
There's another swarm of bees
scattered all over this ridge. They
swarmed in a tree above our wash
stand + we burned them out with
a gasoline torch after dark. The
boys over at the bakery thought
our basha was burning and several
rushed over. The cows are getting
more + more wary. At noon[,] a black
one escaped us[,] but after supper
we caught her on the {b-} path
by the garbage shoot. A letter
from Frank + he has the asthma.
Dec 11 Had to turn the cow loose. The
Gooks are complaining about them
disappearing. Small wonder. Yambrick
stayed at work an extra 30 minutes to
get to tell me he saw last nights'
flat bread. Seabiscuit saw that
the dough didn't move + knew
what to expect but left no orders.
I knew it would come out flat but
baked it off thinking that would be
better than being short. Today
Seabiscuit told Pete it should
have been thrown back. He
said nothing to me. If we
had thrown it back[,] that too
would have been the wrong thing.
The second ball team beat the
first. Spirit was high. Bo Bo
came in late + told Louie about
flour in the floor. Like Seabiscuit
he said nothing to me. Could it be
I'm losing favor with the brass?
If so[,] why do they leave me alone
rather than ride me? I think I've
got the answer. Bo Bo realizes the
company is out from under his
thumb[,] but doesn't want to get
on the leading NCOs for fear
things will get worse + he'll be
off the deep end.
Dec 12 To go with the duck
supper we made 14 pans of
rolls. I baked them off in the
experimental tent. Seabiscuit
lost 5 pounds when one of my
burners gained 20. The whisky
still is in full swing and[,]
from all reports turning out[,]
a satisfactory product.
Tex gave {Primm} the idea
of the experimental tent. {Primm}
put it over with Seabiscuit
and takes credit for it.
Anyone bucking for more
stripes from now on will
be running an experiment
...if an officer is
around.
